Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Liposomal Bupivacaine in Thoracic Surgery

Participants.evidence: 102 patients scheduled for elective thoracoscopic surgery at the Affiliated Hospital of Qingdao University

Intervention.evidence: randomized 1:1 to receive thoracic paravertebral block with LB (6.67 mg/mL) or ropivacaine hydrochloride (RH; 0.33%)

Objective.evidence: This study assessed the impact of liposomal bupivacaine (LB) on postoperative opioid consumption and recovery in patients undergoing thoracic surgery.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was opioid consumption within 72 hours postoperatively.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomization was achieved using fixed block randomization with allocation concealment via sealed opaque envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was maintained for participants, clinicians, and outcome assessors.

Number_Randomised.evidence: From November 1, 2024, to March 10, 2025, 102 patients were randomized (LB group, n = 51; RH group, n = 51).

Number_Analysed.evidence: One patient was excluded, resulting in 101 patients analyzed.

Result_Outcome.evidence: LB significantly reduced 72-hour opioid consumption compared to RH (mean difference = –181.4 mg; 95% CI: –232.8, –130.0 mg; P < 0.001).

Harms.evidence: No significant differences in adverse events were observed between groups.
